image.altText: Bob Hawke

items.synopsis: Bob Hawke returned from the remote Northern Territory in 1988 to a divided, partisan parliament. Some say this sunk the prospect of a treaty before the idea ever got off the ground.

title.children: In 1988, prime minister Bob Hawke promised a treaty with Aboriginal people. Why did it fail?

items.synopsis: How sneaker brands charge up to 10,000 times the cost of manufacturing — and fans eat it up.

title.children: 'Instant credibility': Would you spend $200,000 on a pair of sneakers you can't even wear? Here's why some people do

image.altText: Hunter Biden, dressed in a suit, is seen outside.

items.synopsis: Hunter Biden, the son of US President Joe Biden, is charged with three gun offences, setting him on course for a possible criminal trial as his father campaigns for re-election in 2024.

title.children: Hunter Biden charged with gun crimes after allegedly lying about his drug addiction

image.altText: Taylor Swift stands on stage holding microphone wearing black sparkly leotard with long sleeves.

items.synopsis: Despite a cost-of-living crisis, Australians are willing to spend more to see live music. And some celebrities are finding ways to encourage them.

title.children: 'Staggering' prices and new marketing ploys: How the economics of live music is changing

image.altText: Michaelia Cash in front of a green background

items.synopsis: The federal Coalition will try to overturn the ACT's drug-decriminalisation policy, which reduces penalties for people possessing small amounts of illicit drugs, including cocaine, ice and heroin.

title.children: 'This is madness': Federal opposition will seek to overturn ACT's new drug laws

image.altText: A graduate holds on to his hat while talking on his mobile phone

items.synopsis: A landmark Senate inquiry into sexual consent laws recommends the federal government immediately establish an independent taskforce to hold universities and colleges to account on sexual violence.

title.children: Landmark inquiry recommends immediate creation of taskforce to hold universities to account on sexual violence

image.altText: A black-and-white shot of a middle-aged man in a dark hat and coat, bearing a grim expression.

items.synopsis: In 1951 an SA fisherman ventured out to cast a line into the flooding Murray River. The truth behind the profoundly disturbing discovery he made remains unknown to this day — but that may be about to change.

title.children: Push to solve cold case mystery of petrified woman found without a face, teeth, hands or feet

image.altText: A man in glasses

items.synopsis: Over three years, this Canadian man is alleged to have sent 1,200 self-poison kits to people in 40 countries around the world. Interpol says some of them have reached Australia.

title.children: How the alleged 'poison seller' of Canada may have sent his deadly kits into Australia

image.altText: A cruiseship is stuck in low water, two smaller boats have come up to it, a rugged hillside is in the background

items.synopsis: A luxury cruise ship that ran aground in a remote part of Greenland with 206 people onboard is pulled free by the fishing trawler that first failed to do so a day earlier.

title.children: Cruise ship pulled free after being stuck in mud for three days in Greenland

image.altText: A young man wearing a black collared shirt smiles in close-up

items.synopsis: Hun Manet received "warm congratulations" from Anthony Albanese after becoming Cambodia's prime minister, but members of the Cambodian diaspora in Australia have expressed shock and outrage over the move.

title.children: Hun Manet received 'warm congratulations' from Anthony Albanese, but critics have condemned his inherited power

image.altText: A sign of Wilton Greens says "land now selling".

items.synopsis: China's largest private developer Country Garden invested millions buying and developing prime sites in Australia. Now, it is among several debt-laden developers selling or downsizing their portfolios.

title.children: Chinese developers exit Australian market as property crisis worsens in China

image.altText: A crowd of people protesting, with some people holding signs saying 'not the Queen's land' and holding flags.

items.synopsis: Victoria may not be considered a "battleground" state in the Voice to Parliament referendum, but that doesn't mean the state isn't divided over the upcoming vote.

title.children: Could the No campaign be winning over Australia’s 'most-progressive' state?

image.altText: Defence personnel treat injured koala.jpg

items.synopsis: Australia's war-fighting capability is being compromised by "near-persistent" demands to respond to domestic emergencies, according to findings from a parliamentary inquiry.

title.children: 'Forced to make impossible choices': Domestic demands hamper Defence's war-fighting powers

image.altText: A stock image of a man in a suit holding a plant.

items.synopsis: Advocates are concerned fossil fuel lobby groups are opposing changes to greenwashing regulations in Australia, whilst a new study finds the world's largest transnational companies are failing to provide evidence for their environmental claims.

title.children: Australia's oil and gas lobby group wants the law to step in when people make 'false' claims of greenwashing

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair staring up

items.synopsis: At a meeting in federal parliament today, former patients have told Facebook and Instagram executives how social media undermined their recovery.

title.children: Eating-disorder patients confront Meta bosses at Parliament House as research links TikTok to harmful videos

image.altText: Marcia Langton at a press conference in Parliament House

items.synopsis: Bunburying is the art of concocting a noble-sounding alibi to provide cover for an undisclosed and less-noble objective. Why is this relevant today? Because senior First Nations academic Marcia Langton has been at the centre of a comprehensive Bunburying. Here's what transpired, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: There's a foul, rising tide of racism in the Voice debate ahead of the referendum

image.altText: NASA official wearing suit in front of a NASA logo.

items.synopsis: The space agency released the findings after a yearlong study into unidentified anomalous phenomena.

title.children: NASA's report finds no evidence of 'extraterrestrial origin' for UAP sightings

image.altText: A graphic of dozens of large battery storage units near a power substation.

items.synopsis: A proposal for a new giant battery in Tasmania's Central Highlands has been unveiled — with one energy expert saying the technology has a distinct advantage over the massive, and expensive, Marinus Link undersea cable project.

title.children: 'Batteries and hydropower work together': Clean energy Tasmania set to get its first big battery

image.altText: two children and an adult gather round a sandstone cliff with rock art

items.synopsis: Archaeologists and artificial intelligence specialists have teamed up with Indigenous rangers to document the fragile sandstone paintings.

title.children: 'The old people are smiling': Artificial intelligence helps catalogue Aboriginal rock art in Far North Queensland

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: Kim Jong Un and Vladimir Putin shake hands in front of two flags.

items.synopsis: The Kremlin says Vladimir Putin "gratefully" accepts the invitation, and his foreign minister will travel to Pyongyang in October.

title.children: Putin accepts Kim's invite for North Korea visit, but only his foreign minister looks set to travel

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair smiles at the camera in a hospital bed, holding up 4 fingers, to signify how many surgeries.

items.synopsis: An actor and comedian shares her experience on social media of feeling shamed in a pharmacy when trying to collect her prescribed pain medication.

title.children: Sydney comedian 'overwhelmed' by public response after sharing 'humiliating' experience buying drugs in pharmacy

image.altText: A woman hands a man a pamphlet.

items.synopsis: Western Sydney often makes or breaks federal governments at elections. Now, during the lead-up to the referendum, some communities are saying the Voice is not a priority for them, or that there’s not enough information.

title.children: Disengaged, unaware, undecided: The debate over the Voice in Western Sydney

image.altText: A glass office building with the purple NDIS sign out the front.

items.synopsis: The federal government is set to repeal the Disability Services Act and replace it with a new set of standards, which the Greens say is an opportunity to end the segregation of many disabled people from the rest of the community.

title.children: Changes to disability support outside NDIS with government to implement new set of standards

image.altText: Two smiling people with a golden sunset.

items.synopsis: Tania and Dale are among a growing number of Aussies eager to put the city lights behind them and make the most of abundant work opportunities in rural communities.

title.children: More than 3 million Australians want to move to the outback, according to the Regional Australia Institute

image.altText: A crane works to repair flooding damage on a road. A wall of sandbags blocks flooding.

items.synopsis: The Insurance Council of Australia takes the unusual step of urging a northern Victorian council to reconsider its decision to approve 16 townhouses slated for land that significantly flooded last year.

title.children: Insurance council urges Echuca shire to stop townhouses being built on flood-prone land

image.altText: A man wearing a suit jacket sits and speaks, gesturing with his hands, at a business summit

items.synopsis: Tim Gurner says he regrets comments he made at a media event, which were slammed by workers, unions and politicians.

title.children: Multimillionaire property developer admits comments about 'arrogant' workers were 'deeply insensitive'

image.altText: An aerial photo of a coastal historic city with many destroyed buildings and a wide divide in the middle cleared by a flood

items.synopsis: As the death toll is expected to rise in Libya's disastrous floods, Derna has been hit harder than any other city. Here's how crumbling infrastructure and a decade of political chaos left the region reeling.

title.children: As many as 20,000 may have died. Why has the destruction of Derna's dams caused so much chaos?

image.altText: Clownfish swimming near bleached coral off Lizard Island

items.synopsis: If Australia wants to keep the Great Barrier Reef — not just off the 'in danger' list, but also in existence — much more needs to be done, writes Michael Slezak.

title.children: The uncontroversial truth behind the Great Barrier Reef's 'good news'

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price speaks at a podium at the National Press Club

items.synopsis: Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price tells the National Press Club the Voice to Parliament proposal is "flawed in its foundations".

title.children: 'I will not accept the lie': Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price rails against the Voice in Press Club address

image.altText: A young man in a suit looks down as he stands among a group of people outside a building

items.synopsis: A federal court judge finds the State of Victoria and the principal of Brighton Secondary College breached the Racial Discrimination Act after five students said they were subjected to anti-Semitic bullying.

title.children: Students subjected to anti-Semitic bullying, Nazi symbol graffiti win $435k payout in federal court ruling

image.altText: A group of women wearing yellow and green uniforms standing in a line jump in the air celebrating

items.synopsis: The Matildas' future FIFA Women's World Cup matches have been added to the anti-siphoning list, making it "more likely" Australians will be able to watch them play for free, the federal government says.

title.children: Government takes action to protect future Matildas matches from TV paywalls

image.altText: A large pile of rubble, with mountains visible in the background.

items.synopsis: In the days since a deadly earthquake rippled through Morocco's High Atlas Mountain, devastating stories of loss have emerged. Seismic data and satellite imagery show the sheer scale of this destruction.

title.children: Deep in the Atlas Mountains, a monster was slowly growing. Moroccan villages on top had no chance
